verses.text: Lord, you have been our dwelling place through all generations.
verses.comment: Opening with God as the eternal refuge for His people, this verse reminds us of God's continuous presence. The dwelling place motif is spiritually rich, prefiguring the sanctuary and points to a deeper communion with God, as later fulfilled in Christ (John 1:14).

verses.text: Before the mountains were brought forth, or ever you had formed the earth and the world, from everlasting to everlasting you are God.
verses.comment: Highlights God's eternity and creative power; God is unchanging and everlasting, a foundation for understanding the reality of eternal life promised in Scripture (John 17:3).

verses.text: You turn man back to dust and say, 'Return, O children of man!'
verses.comment: Direct reference to mortality after the Fall (Gen. 3:19), and reminds us of humanity's dependence on God's mercy for revival and resurrection, a theme fulfilled in Christ’s resurrection (1 Corinthians 15:22).

verses.text: For a thousand years in your sight are like yesterday when it has passed, or like a watch in the night.
verses.comment: God is outside of time; this verse is echoed in 2 Peter 3:8, which connects God’s timing to His patience and mercy, anticipating the return of Christ.

verses.text: You sweep them away like a flood; they are like a dream, like grass that sprouts in the morning.
verses.comment: Life's brevity and fragility shown by images of a flood, a dream, and grass; spiritually, it points to the need for rootedness in God’s covenant community as a source of lasting hope.

verses.text: In the morning it flourishes and grows, but in the evening it fades and withers.
verses.comment: Mortality is underscored—our earthly lives are fleeting, yet God’s Word and promises remain forever, as Isaiah reiterates.

verses.text: For we are consumed by your anger, and by your wrath we are troubled.
verses.comment: Recalls Israel’s wilderness judgment (Num. 32), showing the seriousness of sin and the discipline God gives His people. Traditionally seen as a call to repentance, which prepares the soul for salvation.

verses.text: You have set our iniquities before you, our secret sins in the light of your presence.
verses.comment: God’s omniscience makes hidden sins visible. This awareness draws us to seek sacramental forgiveness, emphasizing God’s immense mercy.

verses.text: For all our days pass away under your wrath; we end our years like a sigh.
verses.comment: Human frailty and the weight of sin are lamented, yet this sorrow prepares hearts for the hope of renewal promised by God through His covenants.

verses.text: The days of our life are seventy years, or even, by reason of strength, eighty; yet their pride is but toil and trouble; soon they are gone, and we fly away.
verses.comment: Reflection on the ordinary length of human life, drawing us to consider the afterlife and the promise of resurrection in Christ (John 11:25), encouraging deeper preparation for eternity.

verses.text: Who considers the power of your anger, and your wrath according to the fear that is due you?
verses.comment: Reverence and awe before God’s holiness are essential—'fear of the Lord' is understood not merely as terror but as holy reverence, beginning of wisdom (Prov. 9:10).

verses.text: So teach us to number our days, that we may gain a heart of wisdom.
verses.comment: A prayer for wisdom to appreciate life's brevity. Wisdom has always been understood as a divine gift, leading to true knowledge and intimacy with God.

verses.text: Return, O Lord! How long? Have compassion on your servants.
verses.comment: A yearning for God’s mercy. The heartfelt plea demonstrates a hope in God’s faithfulness, anticipating the incarnation and redemption.

verses.text: Satisfy us in the morning with your steadfast love, so that we may rejoice and be glad all our days.
verses.comment: God’s mercies are new every morning (Lam. 3:23); longing to be filled with God’s love is spiritually fulfilled in the grace offered through Christ.

verses.text: Make us glad for as many days as you have afflicted us, for as many years as we have seen evil.
verses.comment: Petitioning for joy to match past suffering; this echoes the Christian hope in restoration and joy after tribulation, foreshadowed in Christ’s own suffering and glory.

verses.text: Let your work be revealed to your servants, and your glory to their children.
verses.comment: To see God’s works and glory revealed is to participate in God’s redemptive plan, culminating in Christ (John 17:24), and in the ongoing presence of the Spirit among God’s people.

verses.text: Let the favor of the Lord our God be upon us, and establish the work of our hands for us; yes, establish the work of our hands.
verses.comment: The repetition emphasizes the need for God’s grace to make human efforts fruitful. The prayer to be established in God’s favor anticipates the spiritual fruits of a life deeply rooted in faith and the sacraments.
